obligation in the inclosed presentation of the facts and
the twin duty of those in authority to leave us alone in
that presentation. On the whole, despite occasional
lapses, our news columns have been successful in their
object. And, however often we may have questioned
certain policies of the administration and the Student
council, our own rights to free expression has never
been challenged from any official source. That is as it should be.
There have been times when our editorial policy has
not found favor with large sections of the campus. We
hope that this will always be the case. And, for that
reason, whatever the heresies expressed in these col.
urns, the NEWS-LETTER will always have an honored
and conspicuous place for dissenters.
It is quite possible that our editorial columns will
not always he in the right. It is even possible that
the fallibility of man will lead us into some pretty bad
bloomers both now and in the future. But errors_ of
judgment can be corrected. There is no cure for the
sort of spirit, which is so blindly convinced of its own
rectitude that it is intolerant of all other opinion.
Let us hope, most of all, at this second-act curtain,
that that spirit never lays its dead hand on the NEWSLETTER.

ALTHOUGH BEATEN BY A
count of 3-1, the Hopkins baseball
team closed its season at Enunitsburg, Maryland, with the year's beat
performance. Baetjer Miller, held Mt
St Mary's to two hits, one of which
was a four-base blow by that. perennial Hopkins nemesis, Appichella.
Hopkins' lonemarker was a ninth
inning circuit clout by • Captain
Marty Hartke in his last trip to the
plate in a Blue Jay uniform.
After Appichella's homer in the
second frame, the Mounts put on
a hitless two-run rally in the fourth.
Karpinswi walked and went to third
on two outfield outs; McElligott also
had a free trip to first. Both runners
then scored when Schwartzman threw
the ball. to left field trying to pick
Kaminski off third. From then on,
Miller was complete master of the
situation, but Spike Leary proved
just as baffling to the Jay willowwielders, that is all except Johnny
Bateman who slashed out three of
the five Hopkins hits.
It looked like a big ninth inning
.for the Jays. Hartke led the frame off
with his home run. Then, with two
down and two on the bags, Miller
poled out what appeared to be a sure
hit to left field. But once more Appichella ruined the Jays by making
a fine running catch to end the ball
game and the season for Hopkins.
Captain Hartke, Lenny Ftubinger
and Cy Romanoffsky, who, as a reward for his four years of regular
service, was benched in his last game,
completed 'their careers at the Hopkins in this encounter. The team
fared well, winning five and losing
three; next year promises even a
better record with seven regulars
returning. The year's success was
due in no small amounts to the coaching of Alphonse "Tommy" Thomas,
former big-league hurler, who lent a
helping hand this season.

game favorites, walked off the field
with a 9-3 victory over Hopkins Saturday at West Point. It was the second consecutive victory for the West
Pointers over the Blue Jays in as
many years.
The Cadets, clearly superior in attack strength and possessed of
enough advantage in experience,
weight and height, were not in any
great danger from the Hopkins team
at any point in the whole encounter.
Although the Jay ten battled all the
. way, time and time again they were
unable to work the ball in close to
the Army goal.
Gillem, Amick, and Finn were the
big guns for the Academy aggregation with two goals apiece; Brinker,
Bollard, and Hoisington garnered the
The Hopkins
remaining tallies.
markers were made by Enders, Spillman, and Penniman'.
The first goal of the fray was made
by Army in the opening period while
Hopkins was blanked. In the second
the Jays garnered two points, but
Army retaliated with a jackpot of
four. In a skirmish in front of the
Army goal, Spillman rushed in, shovbit and kicked the ball
ed around
into the nk. In the following faceoff Penninmen, with a well-execute
dodge, sent a fast shot past Conner,
the West Point goalie.
In the third frame, Hopkins
.to one tally while the
was held
Army registered three times. With
a Hopkins man in the crease and the
Cadet defense fairly close, Johnny
Enders bounced a slow one past the
Academy goalie. In the final frame
Army added another, but Hopkins
failed to ring the bell.
The Cadets' only obstacle to
national supremacy this year will be
the Midshipmen from Annapolls,
who, Saturday, crashed thru the
University of Maryland defense, in
one of the greatest rallies in the
history of lacrosse, scoring five goals
in the closing minutes of play and
halting the Terps' string of consecutive victories at twenty-three.

museum, but this time the public at
large was admitted. The cast included Mary Stoy Vaughan, Patti Singewald, Mary Alvey, Helen Ascherfeld,
David .Kurland, Myer Site, Ramont
Hamel, S Vannort • Chapman, and
Pbilip Polster. The settings were constructed by the Maryland institute.
In 1934, "Uncle Vanya" was first
produced in Baltimore by the Playshop and met with astounding sue-

cells. The play was so powerful and
the production so impressive that
many of the faculty and the student
body urged that it be repeated. The
Playshop took advantage of the opportunity offered by the Baltimore
Museum of Aet, and revived the play
for one single jserformance before the
general public.

obligation in the inclosed presentation of the facts and
the twin duty of those in authority to leave us alone in
that presentation. On the whole, despite occasional
lapses, our news columns have been successful in their
object. And, however often we may have questioned
certain policies of the administration and the Student
council, our own rights to free expression has never
been challenged from any official source. That is as it should be.
There have been times when our editorial policy has
not found favor with large sections of the campus. We
hope that this will always be the case. And, for that
reason, whatever the heresies expressed in these col.
urns, the NEWS-LETTER will always have an honored
and conspicuous place for dissenters.
It is quite possible that our editorial columns will
not always he in the right. It is even possible that
the fallibility of man will lead us into some pretty bad
bloomers both now and in the future. But errors_ of
judgment can be corrected. There is no cure for the
sort of spirit, which is so blindly convinced of its own
rectitude that it is intolerant of all other opinion.
Let us hope, most of all, at this second-act curtain,
that that spirit never lays its dead hand on the NEWSLETTER.

ALTHOUGH BEATEN BY A
count of 3-1, the Hopkins baseball
team closed its season at Enunitsburg, Maryland, with the year's beat
performance. Baetjer Miller, held Mt
St Mary's to two hits, one of which
was a four-base blow by that. perennial Hopkins nemesis, Appichella.
Hopkins' lonemarker was a ninth
inning circuit clout by • Captain
Marty Hartke in his last trip to the
plate in a Blue Jay uniform.
After Appichella's homer in the
second frame, the Mounts put on
a hitless two-run rally in the fourth.
Karpinswi walked and went to third
on two outfield outs; McElligott also
had a free trip to first. Both runners
then scored when Schwartzman threw
the ball. to left field trying to pick
Kaminski off third. From then on,
Miller was complete master of the
situation, but Spike Leary proved
just as baffling to the Jay willowwielders, that is all except Johnny
Bateman who slashed out three of
the five Hopkins hits.
It looked like a big ninth inning
.for the Jays. Hartke led the frame off
with his home run. Then, with two
down and two on the bags, Miller
poled out what appeared to be a sure
hit to left field. But once more Appichella ruined the Jays by making
a fine running catch to end the ball
game and the season for Hopkins.
Captain Hartke, Lenny Ftubinger
and Cy Romanoffsky, who, as a reward for his four years of regular
service, was benched in his last game,
completed 'their careers at the Hopkins in this encounter. The team
fared well, winning five and losing
three; next year promises even a
better record with seven regulars
returning. The year's success was
due in no small amounts to the coaching of Alphonse "Tommy" Thomas,
former big-league hurler, who lent a
helping hand this season.

game favorites, walked off the field
with a 9-3 victory over Hopkins Saturday at West Point. It was the second consecutive victory for the West
Pointers over the Blue Jays in as
many years.
The Cadets, clearly superior in attack strength and possessed of
enough advantage in experience,
weight and height, were not in any
great danger from the Hopkins team
at any point in the whole encounter.
Although the Jay ten battled all the
. way, time and time again they were
unable to work the ball in close to
the Army goal.
Gillem, Amick, and Finn were the
big guns for the Academy aggregation with two goals apiece; Brinker,
Bollard, and Hoisington garnered the
The Hopkins
remaining tallies.
markers were made by Enders, Spillman, and Penniman'.
The first goal of the fray was made
by Army in the opening period while
Hopkins was blanked. In the second
the Jays garnered two points, but
Army retaliated with a jackpot of
four. In a skirmish in front of the
Army goal, Spillman rushed in, shovbit and kicked the ball
ed around
into the nk. In the following faceoff Penninmen, with a well-execute
dodge, sent a fast shot past Conner,
the West Point goalie.
In the third frame, Hopkins
.to one tally while the
was held
Army registered three times. With
a Hopkins man in the crease and the
Cadet defense fairly close, Johnny
Enders bounced a slow one past the
Academy goalie. In the final frame
Army added another, but Hopkins
failed to ring the bell.
The Cadets' only obstacle to
national supremacy this year will be
the Midshipmen from Annapolls,
who, Saturday, crashed thru the
University of Maryland defense, in
one of the greatest rallies in the
history of lacrosse, scoring five goals
in the closing minutes of play and
halting the Terps' string of consecutive victories at twenty-three.

repeated "Uncle Vanya," at the
museum, but this time the public at
large was admitted. The cast included Mary Stoy Vaughan, Patti Singewald, Mary Alvey, Helen Ascherfeld,
David .Kurland, Myer Site, Ramont

In 1934, "Uncle Vanya" was first
produced in Baltimore by the Playshop and met with astounding sue-

cells. The play was so powerful and
the production so impressive that
many of the faculty and the student
body urged that it be repeated. The
Playshop took advantage of the opportunity offered by the Baltimore
Museum of Aet, and revived the play
for one single jserformance before the
general public.
